								10/10 would plough cockpit-first into a terraformer againAlright, kids.  This isn't your regular racer.  In this game, you'll fly instead of drive.  Hopefully.  If you're driving, you're doing it wrong.    Gameplay: 9/10Graphics: 7/10Sound: 8/10Is this game worth your money?  Yes.  I rate my steam games by how often my heartrate rises above 100 beats per minute, because those are the games that are the most exciting.  This game's gameplay consists of you feeling like a pro while you race over the planes of Mars, and then feeling like an idiot as you narrowly (read: by a hair's breadth) miss a pile of rocks.  The latter occurs more the faster you try to fly.The gameplay is a blend of traditional racers with realistic physics and the ability to trade alitude for airspeed and vice-versa.  Vector 36 FEELS like a traditional racer with just a little bit more depth to it.  It also runs slower than traditional racers, allowing you to savor the feeling of catching up to your foes.  This draws out the chase & pass sequences rather than leaving them down to some cheap pass-on-the-inside-of-the-corner ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, which is what you'd see in a traditional racer.  The graphics aren't Dices' Battlefront quality, but you don't notice that once you begin racing.  The gameplay is so good that it draws you in past its graphics and into the race.  Vector 36 is immersive WITHOUT lifelike graphics, and that's pretty damn admirable.  I should note that I'm playing on a GTX 650, so to be honest I haven't experienced Vector 36's true graphics quality.  Sound: nothing to report.  It's good.  Excellent, in fact.  Sounds realistic.  Adds to the immersion.  Look, point is, it's good.  You'll enjoy it.  And it's only going to keep getting better. 								This is a really unique racing game and likely the first one which uses newton physics. It features races across vast, open landspaces in 5 different speed tiers, kinda like the races in star wars.In most racing games you can only steer left + right. In Vector 36 you can also stear up and down + vertically, which also makes the game really challenging and somewhat hard to learn (at first). All skippers also drift alot if you want to turn, which gives it a great feeling.The lower you fly, the faster you are able to skip across the surface, but it is also more dangerous. This is also a great way to prevent people from just flying around freely.You are able to manage your energy distribution in real time while you are racing. Energy is distributed between stabilizators (lift) and engine power. That means the more energy the engine gets, the more challenging it is to get a stable flight. For example, if you set the engine to 100%, you wont even able to jump above a small hill while setting the engines to 20%, you wont even notice the hill because it will auto adjust the height. This will also affect your turn radius.Because of this, you are constantly adjusting your power management.By doing races you get money and are able to buy new skippersl You can also customize your own vehicle, by buying different parts for your skipper. No multiplayer yet, but it is plannedI can realy recommend it if you want a realistic star wars pod racer style game, but I cant realy recommend it for casual gamers, because the game is very hard to learn and first speed tier is realy slow.i give it 9 of 10 points.

								If you like racing games more oriented to the simulation side where you can adjust mostly every little aspect of your racing machine, then you should try this. Vector 36 sets you in a terraformed Mars, where pilots use their racing machines (called Skimmers) to compete on the circuits of the surface of Mars. These Skimmers are hover machines that you can adjust and fine tune to the millimeter. The game is fully physics driven and offers a very complete garage where you can modify your Skimmers, starting from the angles of every lift to configuring even the force and direction of each of them, all in an intuitive way. If you don’t want to wrap your head around all this, that’s fine too! The game has 3 basic Skimmers from different manufacturers that you can purchase and use them as is and they will work perfectly. You have 6 more customized ones in the shop too, so you have where to choose. The game has 6 circuits right now and an array of special races, like weight or engine power limitations, so definitely there is a nice amount of content from the start (and it will just keep growing!). On top of that, this game has support for the VR headsets, which will make your experience even more enjoyable!So, in conclusion, this game is a little gem that deserves more attention and is a good example of how early access games should be done. From the start, it’s perfectly playable and has a nice amount of content for it’s price tag, not like others that aren’t even playable after months of being released on Steam. The game is constantly in development and have regular updates, so I totally recommend Vector 36!

												(Please check out a full review at thecrankymessiah.com)This game is fantastic.I bought this on a whim and, to be perfectly honest, i didn't even plan on keeping it. I was bored, and i just wanted to play it for an hour or so to see what it was like and then refund it. Because i am a jerk. The next thing i knew, over 3 hours had passed and i was knee-deep in tinkering with my skimmer, trying to get it just right so i could get back to the track and beat the next race.The controls are fantastic. They seem very difficult at first (or at least did to me), and there is definitely a learning curve. But once you get the hang of them (and the physics), which didnt take anywhere near as long as i had feared, they are excellent. It is well worth getting past the initial struggle in order to master them, because once you do this game will make you feel like an absolute bad-a**. Coming down from a jump/bump and tapping your "lift" button while pulling your nose up slightly at JUST the right time to narrowly avoid bouncing off the ground and losing speed, or drifting through a turn and barely avoiding an outcropping or pulling up just enough to skim over it by mere inches, is incredibly gratifying. I don't know that i've ever played a racing game that gave me the same feeling of gratification and satisfaction, let alone of just plain making me feel like an awesome pilot/driver. There is a real, tangible sense of improvement and gradual mastery on the part of the player. Every race, i could feel myself getting just a little bit better, or learning cool new ways to handle my skimmer in certain situations and cut down on my time. It is a hovercraft, rather than a car, so expect a bit of floatiness. But not in a bad way. The physics are impressive. It feels a bit unwieldy at first, but trust me that you will be zooming around and expertly drifting through turns in no time.The skimmer customization is also extremely impressive. Changing parts and setting up your skimmer is not simply a matter of swapping out one part and putting another in its place. The customization options and ability to tinker are much more in-depth, and offer a wealth of potential builds. Parts are placed manually, and can be adjusted in myriad ways. Each part has certain areas on the body in which it can be placed, but they don’t simply snap on to some default location. They can be placed anywhere within those areas. And once you decide where to place them, you are far from done. They can be raised and lowered, as well as rotated on each axis. You COULD just put your new Lift Vector right where one of your old ones was. Or you could set it higher or lower, or rotate it a different way, or put it on a different part of the ship altogether, or still leave the old ones on and just find a good space for the new ones elsewhere on the skimmer (and buy a new radiator to account for the increased heat of the additional parts), or maybe move the back vectors closer to the middle and put the new ones where they were, or maybe you should... you get the idea. There is an almost overwhelming degree of customization. You really are free to tinker with your set-up to a very impressive degree. Even without replacing any parts, and just adjusting the placement of your old ones, you can drastically alter the performance and handling of your skimmer. The same part can have very different effects depending upon where it is placed.Just as importantly, every single tweak you make, from replacing a part to simply rotating it a small degree, has very tangible effects on how your ship handles. Mass, weight, and center of gravity all have very real, pronounced effects on your skimmer. Simply moving a part to a different part of your skimmer can completely alter its center of gravity and change the way it handles. Adding a heavier part completely changes its speed, how well the boost works, how easily and how high you can lift, and so forth. Make your skimmer too heavy, and you’re going to slow down and have a hard time making jumps when necessary, and you may be hugging the ground much more than you like. Make it too light with too much lift, and you’ll become too floaty and have a hard time staying close to the ground at all. I once tried a light build with a lot of lift thinking it would make me fast, and basically turned my skimmer into a metallic balloon; when I hit my boost or tried to lift at all, I floated off high into the air, and basically floated around unable to come back down when I wanted. The direction in which your lift vectors are pointed also have huge effects. Pointing them further in or out completely alters the way the handle and steer. You really must account for everything. You actually have to think about your set-up, and experiment. You have an absolutely massive amount of control over your skimmer, and how it performs. Between the varying effects each individual part can have depending on where and how it is placed, the multiple frames you can use, and the variety of parts at your disposal, there is an almost endless amount of customization and possible builds.Of course, none of that would matter if the racing itself wasn't fun. But thankfully, it's a blast. There's something about flying around Mars in a skimmer that you're fully responsible for building yourself, mastering the physics and controls, that is just a joy. When you finally figure out how to take a turn just right, or use the nuanced controls to narrowly avoid an obstacle without losing speed or damaging your skimmer, you feel like the coolest Skimmer pilot in the universe. I've tried playing with both a keyboard and a Steam Controller, and both work well, although i prefer the controller.Awesome game. I'm not even a huge fan of racing games, and this game has still completely sucked me in. Highly recommend checking it out. And if you do, stick with it. It won't take long to get the hang of it, no matter how hard or unwieldy it seems at the beginning. I hope you enjoy it as much as i have thus far.Now if you'll excuse me, i have this idea for a new set-up i need to try out on my skimmer....

												This game is absolutely fantastic and offers an extremely unique racing experience, but be warned: The learning curve is incredibly steep and the game is absolutely merciless.Patient players who take the time to master the controls and the way skimmers handle will be rewarded with some of the most intense racing I've witnessed so far. Playing in VR feels incredibly good and well optimised skimmers can move very quickly, there's a real sensation of speed and drifting around a corner at 600kph is a harrowing sensation.Getting to the point where you can reliably drive your skimmer will take a while, though, as there's a lot to keep track of. Elevation, heat levels, boost, fuel bias and more all have a very real effect on your craft, and learning how to manage these systems in the middle of a race is key to your victory.You get to design your own skimmer from a decent selection of parts, and the way you put your craft together makes a gigantic difference to the way it controls. Pitching your thrusters the wrong way will gut your speed and handling, distributing the weight unevenly on your craft will cause severe problems at high speeds, and you can even get your hands dirty by individually tweaking the handling and limits of most parts.Chances are you'll spend a good few hours of gameplay making small but significant edits to your craft, then racing, failing, and going back to adjust your craft. For some people, this will be dealbreaker. For me, it's incredibly rewarding and when you finally land on a winning design that suits your playstyle, the feeling is unbeatable.This game isn't easy in any sense of the word, but if you want a challenge that's a refreshing break from the usual car sims, this is definitely worth your time.

This game is in an early access state so I will judge accordinglyTL;DR Great concept with great game play for such an early stage but it needs more time to fulfill its potentialThe GoodVector 36 is a great idea that has so far been well executed, the immersion from using the cockpit on a VR system is great and fits the theme perfectly. The builder system is a nice concept where you can mix and match a small range of parts to create a racer to compete in higher leagues, not quite an armored core range of parts but this is an early stage. Racing rewards risk taking, such as adjusting the 'bias' which basically means you will go faster but at the cost of maneuvering and altitude. I love the concept of this game and even at this early stage it is my go-to VR experience. I was surprised at how easy it was to plug in my X55 and Vive an start playing within minutes, a luxury that even large games struggle with. There is no formal guide as to recommended tactics when making your skimmer although the dev does have some (older) videos on YouTube and there is a discussion section on the community hub, I personally found that 10 hours into the game it all starts to make sense, but some people don't have 10 hours to sink into a game (although if you bought a HMD I suspect you do). Final point - this is an early access game with DLC, the dev has argued that he sees the DLC as a luxury that not all users will need which I can mostly understand, but I sincerely hope that we don't see any Payday 2, Call of duty or other cash grabbing DLC installments in the future.This is shaping up to be a really fun game and if the VR garage problems along with the complexity factors can be worked on I see this being an even better game.Edit 1: Other points after further time with game + Spellcheck

								Playing this game on an HTC Vive with an X55 HOTAS. All the axis' and buttons for the controllers were mapped well by defalt, so I only had to do minimal adjustments to the controller setup to get it to my liking. It took me a little while to understand the basics of how to control the skimmer, but once I got the hang of it - oh boy - this game is an absolute blast! It manages to capture the spirit of traditional (car) racing games, in that you want to return to a track again and again to learn the layout and improve your lap times. At the same time - it doesn't really require lightning reflexes like many other games do - since a lot of inertia is involved in steering the skimmer. You have to plan your moves ahead, especially at higher speeds. I feel it's more about constant risk management. It feels sooo rewarding when you get a perfect drift at high speed though a tight corner. But don't think you've mastered it yet, or else you'll smack in the cliffs at the next turn.The feeling of presence is great. I am in the cockpit, all the instruments are perfectly readable. The engine sounds are intense. The controls feel just about right. Sure, there are a few bugs and things that can (and most likely will) be improved. Occasionally the mouse cursor hangs in the meny, and I have to reboot the whole game. There are sometimes a few missed frames while racing (GTX 980), but for the most part the game runs fluid. Modding the skimme is difficult, as it is not obvious how replacing a part or tweaking the placement / angle of said part will influence the skimmers behaviour. So - until further - I just use the stock skimmers, but there's plenty of fun to be had in those. I very much recommend this game. It has a very interesting gameplay, it has depht, replayability and is just fantastic in VR. Even though it's early access, it feels like a lot more complete game than most other available Vive / VR games on Steam. And when you buy it - don't rage quit after 15 minutes just because you don't understand the controls. It takes a bit of effort to learn the core basics (about an hour in my case), but it's well worth the effort.

Early Access Review
								A masterful physics based racing experience unlike any other.Some spoilers, but only if you're a weirdo who likes to discover physics engine principles through testing.If you are a fan of racing games and vehicle simulators in general, then you owe it to yourself to try Vector 36. If you own an HMD as well, you have zero reasons to miss this one, the VR implementation is spot on. This is precisely the experience I was looking for when I bought my DK2 and a Vive. There have been many attempts in gaming and simulator history to invent a new style of imaginative vehicle. Very rarely is a developer able to forge something that's unique, intuitive, challenging, and fun. Red River has done it; everything else will be gravy.Even for experienced simulator pilots though, this game requires some mental effort from you. If you think you're going to get into the seat of a skimmer and win in your first three attempts like 50cc class Mario kart race, temper those expectations. Think of the experience like how Neil Armstrong must have felt the first time he sat in the LLRV. It's not a plane, it's not a helicopter, it's something different. Even though he was one of the most experienced pilots on the planet at the time, there was a new puzzle for him to learn and master and success was hugely dependant on his careful inputs.If I had to compare piloting the skimmer to a real world analogue it would be my guess that it reacts something like a wing in ground-effect vehicle (WIG.) Although, at a lower gravity with the ground effect pressure being multiplied by downward thruster pressure instead of large wing surfaces. That is, it's feels very much like what is visually happening. You can really start to feel and anticipate the ground effect cushion once you get the hang of it and it becomes a wonderful factor that needs careful management to navigate the purposefully crafted 3D course surfaces successfully. the thruster balance setting (% of power to lift thrusters from total power output) that can be changed on the fly is a critical control to utilize when adjusting your skimmer. Something that would normally be a dynamic setting in the backend of the vehicle physics is open for pilots to experiment with and leverage. Similar to F1's DRS system, it's a physical control that can be played strategically for an advantage on straightaways. My favorite aspect of the physics involved has got to be the dramatic drifts around sharp corners. Similar to turning a hovercraft, things are not based on grip coefficients, but rear thrust vector.  You can set up the ship to have a river tube feel, where only the reward thrust aimed in the correct direction will adjust your major trajectory, or you can add and position lift thrusters that have small wing like components that will act like elevons to cut your trajectory through the atmosphere for more violent turns, pilot blackout effects included :D. I tend to prefer the flat yawing river tube feel. needing precise timing to initiate a flat spin over 100 degrees to change directions quickly, and then float rearward for a period of time before the thrusters set you on your new path. Fantastic stuff. use that "jump" button or perish.The major striking aspect of the gameplay here is the Kerbal style vehicle building and physical consequences that result. It was totally staggering the first time I made a modification to a ship I had become accustomed to and discovered the affect it had on the flight characteristics.  I had replaced the stock radiator of the Firewave ship with a part that had far better cooling and was shaped more like a long vertical turbine blade. Setting the part on the ship was very simple and intuitive. Precise adjustment of it's position was made even easier with minute control of the three rotational axis that the part can sit at. I decided to roll the radiators over the top of the fuselage to act as a sort of spoiler, pushing the ship down with aerodynamics at speed. I thought it might be cool if I could feel some effect, but mostly was positioning it for aesthetics. Well, in the next race I set off as normal down a fairly typical hole-shot straightaway, noticing a slight difference in the float feel of the ship, but wasn't sure if it was psychosomatic or real.  When I got to the first corner I did as I always do "late-brake" by yawing the full rotation of the turn, hitting the booster, and drifting around the wall.  To my wonderment, I started rising into the air, very quickly, what felt like hundreds of feet in a short time. This was definitely different, definitely something had changed.  It took a few laps to really get the feel for the new ship, but what was obvious was that while my radiator positioning was working as I had intended in a straight line, when my ship rotated to drift perpendicular to my direction of travel, the radiators were positioned to act like elevators in a pitch-up condition!!! lifting me up several stories despite the lift thrusters being in a lower, normal state.That was it for me. That was the point that I knew I was experiencing something special. This game was not going to hold my hand and spoon feed me the experience it thought I wanted. This is sandbox engineering done very, very right. Combined with the "gyro" part, presumably acting like a flight controller in a multirotor drone by diverting thrust power to maintain level condition, the 12-course meal of vehicle physics in this game are both extremely deep, but very approachable for those of us who can remember the Jane's combat days. It's not Mario-Kart. It's way way way better.Understandably though, it's not for everyone. There are a lot of people out there who fancy themselves badass virtual pilots when someone else has adjusted all the expos and aero for them. This game requires more thinking than that, and as a result can be immensely rewarding when you discover a formula that rips! But it can also prove frustrating when the results don't match your ideas and there's no virtual mechanic to help walk you through design elements. However, things are happening for a reason, and in a very alpha Minecraft way, it's up you to discover what those patterns of creation are.If your first reaction to the game is "these ships are slow and clunky" I promise you, you are only two race wins away (not remotely hard once you get the feel) from enough cash to purchase a machine that can seriously get your heart going. Spoiler: I recommend not doing any upgrades to the stock ship. Win two races, trade up to the Firewave, buy the radiator with the tier-one cooling power and you have a machine that can endlessly turbo without worrying about heat management. This will give you a seriously fast ship that's still forgiving to control in turns. You can win quite handily with this set up and the speed and stakes get nice and high. Another pro-tip: the jump button is also affected by the turbo button. Used together, you get turbo lift, which can save your♥♥♥♥♥when you mess up your float.Even if Vector 36 fizzles from a lack of player interest (which would be a real tragedy,) I am certain we'll see more from Red River in the future if they keep applying whatever method they have been to create this gem of a cockpit experience. I know enough about vehicle physics and programing to see that this is a true labour of love. That the feeling you get from piloting the skimmers is an obsessively crafted experience, deeply worthy of your time.Top-shelf, Ryan!All my play time has been:-in the Vive-Xbone controller (flawless for testing)-GTX 980 on a 4790K with 16GB DDR3 1866 RAM.

Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Have some money to burn? Don't have a lighter handy? Have some harddrive space handy instead? Here's your solution. Eh, if you want a tweaker racing game you're better off playing Nascar. While this is certainly very interesting, there's very little to add to the value of the game right now. The Dev has also decided to shill out some nonsense for some human dollars in pre-alpha DLC, so take that for what you will. But what is Vector 36? Its fantastic, when it wants to be. The racing feels like you're podracing without midichlorians and whiney child-actors. A single wrong move will splatter your dumb carcass over the nearest rock and the race will end for you in the sense there's no way you'd be able to catch up. You get repaired by a little drone-thing mid-race if you do lose some parts, which is nice, but you have to wait for it to start paying attention, then find your broken parts strewn across the landscape, then weld it back roughly where it went before.Wether or not it works after you're 'repaired' is entirely up to how many radiators you strapped on to begin with, and how many work after crashing. PROS: > Its fun to go 700+ mph> Its fun to mess with the AI racers, even if they tend to follow exactly the same line of movement. I like slamming into their radiors and watching them slowly burn up when they break off. > Its fun to watch the AI crash and burn around a simple corner> Its fun to build your skimmerCONS:> Its not fun slamming into a wall at 700+ mph because you don't have a perfectly tuned skimmer and it turns out you lose all steering above or below a certain speed and 'bias', which is the ratio between the lift thrusters and the forward thrusters. > Its not fun to grind through the same race over and over again to get the next part or chassis, especially considering the AI have better parts and go faster by default because of this, nevermind their near perfect piloting against your unexperianced hands> Its not fun to pay $4.50 of your human dollars for a few garage slots in an alpha game that already asks for a lump sum of $17.00. I'll recommend it, but only for the promise of future development and my lust for a true death-race style game that has good tweaking. Not if you want a finished product, for obvious reasons.
